findings.title: A previously frozen new owner account cannot be unfrozen
findings.description: Since the unfreezeAddress() function restricts allowed addresses to non-owner accounts only, a previously frozen account that becomes the new owner of the contract cannot be unfrozen unless they relinquish contract ownership.

findings.title: Function destroy() allows contract owner to confiscate the tokens of all token holders
findings.description: In its current implementation, destroy() essentially prevents token holders from assuming any reasonable amount of ownership over the USD pegged tokens they have.

findings.title: approveAndCall() is unexpectedly increasing approved amount instead of only setting it
findings.description: Users calling approveAndCall() will be expecting it to assign an allowance of their given amount to their given spender address, and not add to the spender's already existing allowance.

findings.title: decreaseSupply() allows contract owner to confiscate tokens from any account
findings.description: In its current implementation, decreaseSupply() essentially prevents token holders from assuming any reasonable amount of ownership over the USD pegged tokens they have.

findings.title: Fallback function is redundant
findings.description: The fallback function is redundant as contracts without a fallback function automatically revert payments starting from Solidity 0.4.0.

findings.title: burn() function not needed for all token holders
findings.description: Having burn() function open to the public can potentially pose unnecessary risks for all token holders.

findings.title: Variable name newOwner is confusing
findings.description: The variable 'newOwner' holds the value of an owner pending acceptance, and not the actual new owner of the contract.
